content.description: Deep water solo. Climb directly up to the prominent crack left of the alcove, then follow in right. Cliff jump from the alcove into the water below (approximately 20-25 feet). Swim right and climb up at the bottom of the Indigo Line. Climb rating as been increased by one level due to potential injury from slipping.
content.protection: Deep water below. Push off of cliff before falling. Bomber trees up top for a TR anchor, would allow for more vertical climbing.
content.location: Access by boat. Start on a small ledge below and slightly left of the alcove. About 10 feet left of the ledge with small pine trees growing on it.

content.description: Deep water solo. Climb left to the crack on the right side of the face. Step down before continuing to move left and up towards the alcove. Take the low line along the left-leaning crack (solid red) or the high line by stepping up and following the horizontal crack (dotted red). Cliff jump from the alcove into the water below (approximately 20-25 feet). Swim right and climb up at the bottom of the Indigo Line. Climb rating as been increased by one level due to potential injury from slipping.
content.protection: Deep water below. Push off of cliff before falling. Take caution during first 10 feet of traverse where rock below sticks out a couple feet further than the rest of the climb. Fall at this part of the climb could result in serious injury.
content.location: Access from the right side of the face, a popular cliff jumping section. Step left into a horizontal crack and begin traverse.

content.description: Climb the arete up to the popular cliff jumping spot. Lots of lichen, but good footing. Climb rating as been increased by one level due to potential injury from slipping.
content.protection: Deep water below to the left of the arete, shallow to the right. If a fall is necessary push off left to avoid any potential injuries.
content.location: Scramble down from the popular cliff jumping spot (or swim from jumping) and start right of the cliff face at the water's edge.

content.description: Climb up the right-facing corner, that's all there is to it. Top out and descend right.
content.protection: Bomber tree above, might be possible to set up a TR. Otherwise use caution as there is only solid rock below and a fall could result in a serious injury (without a pad).
content.location: Start on the popular cliff jumping spot, located on the right side of the face.

content.description:
Climb the obvious thin crack and steep face in the whiter rock left of the main face. (See "topo" posted to "Diagional Crack") Wire nuts are very useful.  

  The climb was brushed on a terribly hot summer day, the brushed-off lichen becoming the "dry rain". Fortunately it was easily washed off in the lake!
content.protection:
Wired stoppers, couple of quickdraws. 

  The climb was wire brushed in July 1999.
content.location: On the Climber's-left side of the face, drop down to a flat area a few feet above the water line. (Sorry, no deep-water-solo-belay on this route)

climbs.name: The Diagonal Crack
climbs.fa: ?FA?  ACB: R Hall & S Matz July 1999

content.description: START: just to the left of Dry Rain, branch out right following the obvious diagonal crack. See "Topo/Sketch" posted to Dry Rain.
content.protection:
std rack 

  The climb was wire brushed in July 1999.

content.description: Deep water solo. Climb up and right to the main crack on the left side of the face. Continue right along the prominent crack to the alcove in the middle. Cliff jump from the alcove into the water below (approximately 20-25 feet). Swim right and climb up at the bottom of the Indigo Line. Climb rating as been increased by one level due to potential injury from slipping.
content.protection: Deep water below. Push off of cliff before falling. Bomber trees up top for a TR anchor, would allow for more vertical climbing.
content.location: Access by boat. Start on a small ledge directly below the large crack on the left side of the face.

content.description:
Climb straight up the obvious crack system in the center if the face. Climb #4 0n the "topo/sketch" posted to "Diagional Crack". 

  The first few feet seem to be the same as "Cyan Line", then "Cyan" branches to the right.
content.protection: Deep water solo (gotta push off hard near the top) or TR

content.description: South-facing rock cliff on Bluff Island in Lower Saranac Lake. Plenty of cracks, much of the face is covered in lichen, but still has excellent holds. Traverse in from the East side or start by boat (when the water is calm enough). Excellent deep water soloing. Bomber trees up top for a TR, but need lots of webbing or rope to reach the edge.
